Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Story:
My phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Miss you!” I glance at the clock—already past noon. I’d meant to call her last night, but I got caught up outlining tomorrow’s mentoring session. My mentee, Sarah, is counting on me to walk her through the project workflow before the big deadline. She’s nervous, and I promised I’d be available for questions, even outside our scheduled time. 

But now, as I stare at my phone, guilt creeps in. Mom and Dad expect me to check in, to share little updates and reassure them I’m okay. I know how much it means to them, especially since I moved out. Yet, my mind is tangled in lesson plans and slides, worried I’ll let Sarah down if I don’t give this my full attention. 

I want to be the reliable daughter who calls home, the mentor who’s always prepared. But right now, I can’t seem to be both. My thumb hovers over the call button, my laptop open to my notes, heart pulled in two directions as I try to decide which role needs me more.
